text: Or is trend really a beta timing factor? And if it's really the latter, then there are some nuances in terms of implementation that I think are important. And if you look at when trend has big years, it's not making hay from spreads between related markets. It's really making hay from being directly right across a broad swath of markets. And so that has some implications for how we should implement it. Carry is fundamentally not that different from a valuation signal, right? It's a yield, an earnings yield in this case, but like an actual how much I expect to get paid if the world doesn't change type of yield. And we use carry divided by recent measures of volatility or forecasts of volatility to be sort of a sharp ratio estimate. And so what both trend and carry can do is they can tell me not just within a cross-section of an asset class where I want to be allocated, but it turns out that they're also predictive cross-asset. So if the spread between high and low yielding currencies is... Big relative to the spread between high and low yielding bond futures, for example, then I want to do more FX spread. And it turns out to be the case that that cross-asset carry metric is also predictive. In trend space, if one asset class has a bigger trend signal than another asset class, I typically would want to have more exposure to the asset class that's trending more with some caveats, right? Like if it's overextended, blah, blah, blah. But basically, trend is also predictive cross-asset. And then in the third dimension, cross-time, trend is predictive. If markets are trending heavily, maybe that's a good time to do more trend. If markets are not trending, hard to explain to investors why you have a big allocation of trend. So what we think about is this set of super factors carrying trend. They're super factors because they don't just explain the cross-section of a single asset class, but they explain cross-asset and cross-time. And so they allow us to build a more nuanced portfolio. Frankly, they allow factor time. So if you're focused on these factors, they're very complimentary. They semi-negatively correlate with each other, which is phenomenal. Like value and momentum in equity space. And they're informative in these three dimensions. And so you can build a more nuanced portfolio. You're not just sort of saying, I want to allocate 5% of my risk to each of these 20 factor slash asset class combinations. And so you have a more intelligent portfolio.
